definition: divinatory diagram/one of the eight divinatory trigrams of the Book of Changes 易經|易经[Yi4 jing1]/one of the sixty-four divinatory hexagrams of the Book of Changes 易經|易经[Yi4 jing1]
to resign/to dismiss/to decline/to take leave/ballad (archaic poetic genre)/variant of 詞|词[ci2]
to assist a ruler in governing a country/prime minister

three principles and five virtues (idiom)/the three rules (ruler guides subject, father guides son and husband guides wife) and five constant virtues of Confucianism (benevolence 仁, righteousness 義|义, propriety 禮|礼, wisdom 智 and fidelity 信)
Zou Yan (305-240 BC), founder of the School of Yin-Yang of the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)
to plan and consider/to reflect on one's best strategy
see 八風穴|八风穴[ba1 feng1 xue2]
Baopuzi, collection of essays by Ge Hong 葛洪[Ge3 Hong2] on alchemy, immortality, legalism, society etc
to reach everywhere/to stop at nothing/to do one's utmost
"eight principles," a method of giving a general description and syndrome differentiation (TCM)
to review the old and know the new (idiom, from the Analects)/to recall the past to understand the future
